Award.AwardTitle: Noyce Scholarship Track Phase I: UTeaChattanooga Noyce Scholarship Program (UNSP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Chattanooga's (UTC) College of Arts and Science, College of Health, Education and Professional Studies, Hamilton County schools and four other area school systems are collaborating to produce more and better quality secondary mathematics and science teachers. Specifically, the Noyce Scholarship Program is providing up to 30 two-year scholarships to 15 junior and senior STEM majors in the UTeaChattanooga program at UTC who commit to completing four years of teaching at the high school level in high-needs school districts and up to 80 internships for Freshman and Sophomore STEM majors. The goals of the UTeaChattanooga Noyce Scholarship Program are: (1) to attract highly qualified STEM majors to secondary science and mathematics teaching careers in high-needs schools; (2) to encourage traditionally underrepresented groups in the STEM disciplines to major in STEM fields and seek secondary teacher licensure in mathematics and science; (3) to provide pedagogically and content/research rich experiences to STEM majors seeking secondary teaching licensure; (4) to increase the number of secondary math and science secondary educators, (5) to improve the mathematical and scientific preparation of these educators and (6) to provide comprehensive induction support for UTeaChattanooga Noyce Scholarship Program Scholars (UNSPSs) during their first two years of teaching, with special emphasis on the unique challenges of high-needs schools and their students. The UNSP program provides a choice of six intensive summer internships that strengthen the Scholars' content and research knowledge and provide pedagogically rich experiences for up to 110 UTeaChattanooga students across the five-year grant period. The UNSP initiative is enhancing the infrastructure for research and education through its research and pedagogical opportunities and partnerships with UTC faculty, Department of Energy National Laboratories, the Tennessee Aquarium and UTC's Upward Bound program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Track 1: Chattanooga STEM Education Noyce Scholarship Program (CSENSP) program are to:

  • Attract highly qualified STEM majors to secondary STEM teaching careers in high needs schools;
  • Encourage traditionally underrepresented groups in the STEM disciplines to major in STEM fields and seek secondary teacher licensure in mathematics and science;
  • Provide pedagogically and content/research rich experiences to STEM Education students;
  • Increase the number of secondary math and science secondary educators,
  • Improve the mathematical and scientific preparation of these educators, and
  • Provide comprehensive induction support for CSENSs during their first three years of teaching, with special emphasis on the unique challenges of high needs schools and their students.

The short term outcomes are as follows:

  • SHORT Years 1-2 Students take content-rich courses to help further deepen their conceptual understanding of STEM fields as well as STEM Education courses that help prepare them to be more competent STEM teachers 
  • First cohort of ChattState transfer students participate in the transfer program 
  • CCSS & UTC STEM Summer Scholars become Noyce scholars
  • 6th cohort of UNSP & First cohort of CSENSP scholars enter into teaching field after graduating and participate in the induction program

The medium outcomes are as follows:

  • Second cohort of CSENSP NOYCE scholars graduate and enter into teaching field and participate in the induction program
  • Enrollment of Transfer students increased by 50%, students have a smoother transition
  • 25-30% Eligible transfer students become Noyce Scholars 
  • First cohort of NOYCE scholars graduate and enter two year service to high needs schools 
  • Increasing the knowledge and understanding of teaching science and mathematics in high need schools (urban & rural)??UNSP Noyce Scholars (Track 1-Cohorts 1 & 2) enter the become mentor teachers enter the Noyce Track 2 and/or 3 programs? 

The long term outcomes are as follows:

  • First cohort of transfer students graduate and become STEM Teachers and are provided induction support 
  • Increased teacher retention in STEM Education 
  • UNSP Noyce Scholars become mentor teachers and STEM Education leaders in Hamilton County and surrounding high need LEAs
  • Increase underrepresented populations in STEM entering into STEM fields
  • First cohort of NOYCE scholars complete their required teaching commitment at a high need school district 
  • Providing more solid research in regards to preparing STEM education pre-service teachers to teach in high needs schools
